narrower.prefLabel: Digital identification of LGBTQ+ people by police

hasTopConcept.prefLabel: Identification of LGBTQ+ people by police

record.comment: Identification of LGBTQ+ people, or people believed to be LGBTQ+, by police using any of various tools and mechanisms, many of which are pseudoscientific in nature. Such data is then used to entrap and prosecute LGBTQ+ persons, especially in areas where being LGBTQ+ is still criminalized.
An activity where a person is struck repeatedly, with or without an implement, for erotic play.
Medical practice of achieving fertilization by combining sperm and eggs in laboratory settings to induce pregnancy.
The practice or policy of providing equal access and support to groups of people who might otherwise be excluded or marginalized, such as LGBTQ+ people, people of color, disabled people, etc.
Asexual people who were born in India or are of Indian descent. Do not conflate with the Indigenous peoples of the United States.
Bisexual people who were born in India or are of Indian descent. Do not conflate with the Indigenous peoples of the United States.
Gay men who were born in India or are of Indian descent. Do not conflate with the Indigenous peoples of the United States.
Intersex people who were born in India or are of Indian descent. Do not conflate with the Indigenous peoples of the United States.
Lesbians who were born in India or are of Indian descent. Do not conflate with the Indigenous peoples of the United States.
LGBTQ+ people who were born in India or are of Indian descent. Do not conflate with the Indigenous peoples of the United States.
Queer people who were born in India or are of Indian descent. Do not conflate with the Indigenous peoples of the United States.
Transgender people who were born in India or are of Indian descent. Do not conflate with the Indigenous peoples of the United States.

Asexual people who are part of an Indigenous people, or culturally distinct ethnic group whose members are directly descended from the earliest known inhabitants of a particular region and, to some extent, maintain the language and culture of those people. Only use to describe people who identify as Indigenous; use more specific terms whenever possible.

Bisexual people who are part of an Indigenous people, or culturally distinct ethnic group whose members are directly descended from the earliest known inhabitants of a particular region and, to some extent, maintain the language and culture of those people. Only use to describe people who identify as Indigenous; use more specific terms whenever possible.

Gay men who are part of an Indigenous people, or culturally distinct ethnic group whose members are directly descended from the earliest known inhabitants of a particular region and, to some extent, maintain the language and culture of those people. Only use to describe people who identify as Indigenous; use more specific terms whenever possible.

Intersex people who are part of an Indigenous people, or culturally distinct ethnic group whose members are directly descended from the earliest known inhabitants of a particular region and, to some extent, maintain the language and culture of those people. Only use to describe people who identify as Indigenous; use more specific terms whenever possible.

Lesbians who are part of an Indigenous people, or culturally distinct ethnic group whose members are directly descended from the earliest known inhabitants of a particular region and, to some extent, maintain the language and culture of those people. Only use to describe people who identify as Indigenous; use more specific terms whenever possible.

related.prefLabel: Police harassment of Indigenous LGBTQ+ people

record.comment: LGBTQ+ people who are part of an Indigenous people, or culturally distinct ethnic group whose members are directly descended from the earliest known inhabitants of a particular region and, to some extent, maintain the language and culture of those people. Only use to describe people who identify as Indigenous; use more specific terms whenever possible.

Queer people who are part of an Indigenous people, or culturally distinct ethnic group whose members are directly descended from the earliest known inhabitants of a particular region and, to some extent, maintain the language and culture of those people. Only use to describe people who identify as Indigenous; use more specific terms whenever possible.

Transgender people who are part of an Indigenous people, or culturally distinct ethnic group whose members are directly descended from the earliest known inhabitants of a particular region and, to some extent, maintain the language and culture of those people. Only use to describe people who identify as Indigenous; use more specific terms whenever possible.
Term used to describe the identity of people who are both Indigenous and queer and view those identities as inherently related and interconnected.

Indigenous queer people who recognize their queer identity as salient to their Indigenous identity and vice versa; some but not all Indigiqueer people also identify as Two-Spirit; only use to describe individuals who self-identify as Indigiqueer.
Inflation of the body, parts of the body, clothing, or inflatable objects with air or other substances for sexual arousal or erotic play.
Process by which information is provided to individuals or communities.

The practice of weighing all options and considering evidence, alternatives, and potential risks in order to make a truly informed medical decision. Such decisions are best made over a period of time rather than under pressure.
The act of using sperm to induce pregnancy by natural or artificial means, especially in the context of LGBTQ+ family planning with sperm donors.
Ongoing connections (romantic, sexual, play, or platonic) between two or more people of different age groups or from different generations.

The phenomenon in which bisexual people internalize or adopt biphobic beliefs (i.e., negative perceptions of and intolerance toward bisexual people and bisexuality) as a result of being raised or socialized within a biphobic environment or culture.

This term is often used to describe internalized oppression held by and about LGBTQ+ people in general. It can also describe the more specific phenomenon in which gay men internalize or adopt homophobic beliefs (i.e., negative perceptions of and intolerance toward gay men and homosexuality) as a result of being raised or socialized within a homophobic environment or culture.

The phenomenon in which intersex people internalize or adopt intersexphobic beliefs (i.e., negative perceptions of and intolerance toward intersex people and intersex variations) as a result of being raised or socialized within a intersexphobic environment or culture.

The phenomenon in which lesbians internalize or adopt lesbophobic beliefs (i.e., negative perceptions of and intolerance toward lesbians and lesbianism) as a result of being raised or socialized within a lesbophobic environment or culture.

The phenomenon in which someone in a marginalized group internalizes or adopts oppressive beliefs (i.e., negative perceptions of and intolerance toward any marginalized identities they hold) as a result of being raised or socialized within an oppressive environment or culture.

The phenomenon in which queer people internalize or adopt queerphobic beliefs (i.e., negative perceptions of and intolerance toward queer people and queerness) as a result of being raised or socialized within a queerphobic environment or culture.

The phenomenon in which transgender people internalize or adopt transphobic beliefs (i.e., negative perceptions of and intolerance toward transgender people and trans identities) as a result of being raised or socialized within a transphobic environment or culture.
Websites designed to facilitate discussion amongst users through posted messages.

A theoretical framework first conceptualized by Kimberlé Crenshaw to describe how different facets of social identity (such as gender, race, ethnicity, disability, socioeconomic class, religion, and sexual identity) overlap and intersect, often compounding the individual's experiences with inequality and discrimination.

An umbrella term used to refer to people born with variations in their physical sex characteristics--including genitals, gonads, chromosomes, and hormonal factors--that do not fit typical definitions of male or female bodies.
Direct action and organizing to achieve political or social change, bodily autonomy, and acceptance for intersex people.
Collections of records and materials relating to intersex people or intersex communities; can include a variety of organizations and institutions from community to government archives.
Term for different forms of creative activity, including visual, material, and performing arts, by intersex artists or about intersex topics and communities.
Artists who are intersex
Intersex people who are atheists.
Professional or amateur sports players who are intersex.
Creators of written works who are known to be intersex.
Intersex people who are autistic.
Accounts of individuals' lives written by those individuals; use for autobiographies written by intersex authors.
Written accounts of the lives of individuals known to be intersex.
Intersex people with significant or total loss of vision.
Bookshops that sell materials intended for use by intersex people or addressing topics related to intersex experiences.
Intersex people who are Buddhist.
Characters in creative works who are intersex.
Intersex people who are trained, professional cooks, typically holding a leadership role in the kitchen in which they are employed.
Children younger than 18 years who describe themselves as intersex.
Intersex people who are Christian.
Intersex people who are ordained for religious duties, particularly in the Christian Church.
Intersex people who are attending college.
Intersex people who seek to entertain an audience by making them laugh, through jokes, slapstick, employing prop comedy, or other amusing means.
Works consisting of sequential images often accompanied by text; use in reference to comics focusing on intersexual characters or themes.
Groups of people who share the experience of being intersex.
Spaces in which people from intersex communities meet for social, education, recreational, or organizing activities.
Partnerships in which both people are intersex.

Cultural experiences shared by members of intersex communities or products of intersex culture (e.g., art and media created by and for intersex people, activism focused on intersex issues, slang commonly used in intersex communities, etc.).
Daughters who identify as intersex. Only use for people who identify as daughters.

Intersex people with significant or total hearing loss. Some but not all Deaf people prefer to capitalize Deaf in recognition of the cultural and linguistic identity they share with other Deaf people.
Intersex people who are disabled.
Works of fiction written to be performed; use in reference to dramatic works focusing on intersex characters or themes.
Employment of intersex people.
Erotic art, created by intersex artists, depicting intersex people, or that are regarded as important within intersex culture.
Erotic films or movies, created by intersex directors, depicting intersex people, or that are regarded as important within intersex culture.
Literary works that have erotic or sexual elements; use in reference to erotic literature focusing on intersex characters or themes.
Families, whether biological, adoptive, or chosen, in which one or more individuals are intersex.
Genre that uses magic and other supernatural phenomena as a primary element of plot, theme, and/or setting; use for fantasy fiction focusing on intersex characters or themes.
Intersex people who are fathers. Only use for people who identify as fathers.
Written works of fiction featuring intersex characters or addressing intersex themes.
Motion pictures, or movies, created by intersex directors, depicting intersex people, or that are regarded as important within intersex culture.

Surgeries or other medical treatments performed, typically on newborn babies or children, to "normalize" the patient's reproductive or sexual anatomy and force their body to conform to medical or social expectations for what is male or female. IGM practices can be performed for cultural, social, or religious reasons. Though they are typically justified through a medical lens, IGM practices are medically unnecessary and non-consensual.
Works consisting of sequential images often accompanied by text that generally contain stand-alone stories; used in reference to graphic novels focusing on intersex characters or themes.
Past events or accounts of the past concerning intersex people, or people who might be perceived as intersex if they were alive today.
Written works of fiction intended to frighten, scare, or disgust; use in reference to horror fiction focusing on intersex characters or themes.

Used to describe the experience of selfhood of intersex people. Intersex identity is not gender identity, sexual identity, nor sexual orientation. For the subject of intersex variations, use "intersex variations" or "intersex". For the subject of intersex people, use "intersex people". Do not use in place of gender-identity-related terms such as non-binary identity or genderfluid identity.
Institutions providing education, support, and information about intersex issues and intersex communities to intersex people.
Libraries that hold materials primarily pertaining to intersex people or intended for use by intersex people.

The study, evaluation, and interpretation of literary works focusing on intersex characters or themes; can also include interpretation of literature through the lens and frameworks of intersex studies.
Written literary works about intersex characters or themes.
Intersex people who are mothers. Only use to describe individuals who identify as mothers.
Umbrella term for activism focused on the rights of intersex people and issues faced by intersex communities.
Institutions dedicated to the storage, exhibition, conservation, and preservation of materials relating to intersex people and intersex history.
Musicals created by intersex directors, depicting intersex individuals, or that are regarded as important within intersex culture.
Intersex people who are Muslim.
Written literary works about the investigation of crime or the work of detectives; use in reference to mystery and detective fiction focusing on intersex characters and themes.

Intersex people whose brains process, learn, and/or behave differently from what is considered typical by society. Some of these neurological differences can present as learning disabilities, medical disorders, and other conditions.
Serialized print or digital periodicals created by or for intersex people, often with the purpose of sharing news and information related to intersex communities and intersex issues.

Serialized print or digital publications about intersex issues (and typically produced by intersex people or intersex organizations) that contain news, articles, columns, correspondence, and advertisements.
Operas created by intersex directors, depicting intersex individuals, or that are regarded as important within intersex culture.

Intersex people who are members of polytheistic religions or other religions outside of the dominant culture that typically incorporate nature worship and/or the sacred feminine, such as Wicca, Druidry, Heathenry, etc. Use to describe intersex people who self-identify as Pagan.
Parents who are intersex.
Intersex people who are the romantic, sexual, or play partners of another person or people.

Individuals born with variations in their genitalia, hormones, internal anatomy, and/or chromosomes that do not fully or exclusively conform to medical or social expectations for males or females. Only use to describe people who describe themselves as intersex.
The participation and inclusion of intersex people in fan communities.
Intersex people serving in state and national armed forces.
The presence of intersex people in the workplace, including acceptance of and issues faced by intersex workers.
Intersex people who are not white and who identify as people of color.

Intersex people who have long-term health conditions that require continued medical attention and/or significantly impact or limit daily life; some but not all people with chronic illnesses consider themselves disabled.
Literary work, typically written in verse, that focuses on intersex characters, themes, or identity.
Intersex people working to bring about political or social change through public organizing.
Intersex people who are candidates for public office, are currently holding public office, or have held political positions. Politicians can be elected by public election or otherwise appointed.
Erotic or sexually explicit films featuring intersex people.
Newspapers, magazines, or other publishing outlets aimed at intersex audiences and/or operated by intersex people.
Intersex people who are members of the Protestant Church.
Companies and organizations that publish materials for intersex communities or addressing intersex issues.
Auditory content broadcast on the radio (analog or digital) about intersex people and intersex issues.
Ongoing connections (romantic, sexual, or platonic) between two or more intersex people.

Legal, social, or ethical principles of freedom or entitlement held by intersex people. Often used to refer to intersex people's right to bodily autonomy and, specifically, their right to delay or decline unnecessary medical interventions.
Intersex people who are members of the Roman Catholic Church.
Works of fiction revolving around romantic and/or sexual relationships between the main characters; use in reference to romance fiction focusing on intersex characters.

Written literary work about imaginative or futuristic concepts incorporating science, technology, space, time travel, and other speculative elements; use in reference to science fiction focusing on intersex characters or themes.
Written literary works that are short in length and detail a self-contained incident or concept; use in reference to short stories focusing on intersex characters or themes.
Colloquial or informal language related to intersex identity or used by intersex people.
Intersex people who are sons. Only use to describe individuals who identify as sons.
Academic field of research and study about intersex people, intersex identity, and intersex communities.

Non-lifesaving cosmetic procedures intended to change and "normalize" natural variations in genital appearance and/or reproductive anatomy. Intersex surgery was first developed in the early 20th century, with doctors making unresearched claims about an "urgent need" for these operations.
Intersex people who have experienced and survived bullying directed toward them because they are intersex; follow the individual's preference for "victims" or "survivors" whenever possible.
Intersex people who have experienced and survived hate crimes; follow the individual's preference for "victims" or "survivors" whenever possible.
Intersex people who have experienced and survived rape; follow the individual's preference for "victims" or "survivors" whenever possible.
Intersex people who have experienced and survived sexual abuse; follow the individual's preference for "victims" or "survivors" whenever possible.
Intersex people who have experienced and survived war; follow the individual's preference for "victims" or "survivors" whenever possible.
Television shows featuring intersex characters or themes.
Works in the performance arts that focus on intersex characters or themes.
A subgenre of fantasy fiction featuring magic and supernatural creatures in contemporary urban settings; use for urban fantasy focusing on intersex characters or themes.

Term used to refer to a wide range of variations in sex characteristics. The term "intersex conditions" is a pathologizing term used to mean people born with variations in their physical sex characteristics also known as intersex traits.

Intersex people who have experienced bullying directed toward them because they are intersex and may or may not have survived; follow the individual's preference for "victims" or "survivors" whenever possible.
Intersex people who have experienced hate crimes and may or may not have survived; follow the individual's preference for "victims" or "survivors" whenever possible.
Intersex people who have experienced sexual abuse and may or may not have survived; follow the individual's preference for "victims" or "survivors" whenever possible.
Intersex people who have experienced war and may or may not have survived; follow the individual's preference for "victims" or "survivors" whenever possible.
Intersex people’s legal rights to be informed, present, and heard within the criminal justice system after having been harmed or injured as the result of of a crime, accident, or other event.
Intersex people who use wheelchairs.
Intersex practitioners of Wicca or other Pagan religions who self-identify as witches.
Intersex people between the age of childhood and adulthood.
Written literary works for an audience of readers from 12-18 years of age, also known as young adult literature or YA; use in reference to youth literature focusing on intersex characters or themes.
Independent, small-circulation publications usually reproduced via photocopier; use for zines created by intersex people and/or focusing on intersex identity, issues, or culture.
Businesses focusing on intersex clientele and products related to intersex communities.
Businesses owned by intersex people.

Antagonism or disgust directed toward intersex people or intersex variations. Intersexphobia can include the denial of the existence of intersex people, insistence that intersex variations should be forcibly "corrected," stereotypes, verbal harassment, and physical violence.
Acts of violence or abuse directed against an individual by their current or former partner in a romantic, sexual, or play relationship.
Unwillingness to accept or affirm LGBTQ+ people or their identities in attitude or practice.

Asexual people who are Inuit, or part of several Indigenous peoples inhabiting the Inuit homeland in the Arctic and subarctic regions of Greenland, Canada, and Alaska. Only use for people who identify as Inuit.

Bisexual people who are Inuit, or part of several Indigenous peoples inhabiting the Inuit homeland in the Arctic and subarctic regions of Greenland, Canada, and Alaska. Only use for people who identify as Inuit.

Gay men who are Inuit, or part of several Indigenous peoples inhabiting the Inuit homeland in the Arctic and subarctic regions of Greenland, Canada, and Alaska. Only use for people who identify as Inuit.

Intersex people who are Inuit, or part of several Indigenous peoples inhabiting the Inuit homeland in the Arctic and subarctic regions of Greenland, Canada, and Alaska. Only use for people who identify as Inuit.

Lesbians who are Inuit, or part of several Indigenous peoples inhabiting the Inuit homeland in the Arctic and subarctic regions of Greenland, Canada, and Alaska. Only use for people who identify as Inuit.

LGBTQ+ people who are Inuit, or part of several Indigenous peoples inhabiting the Inuit homeland in the Arctic and subarctic regions of Greenland, Canada, and Alaska. Only use for people who identify as Inuit.

Queer people who are Inuit, or part of several Indigenous peoples inhabiting the Inuit homeland in the Arctic and subarctic regions of Greenland, Canada, and Alaska. Only use for people who identify as Inuit.

Transgender people who are Inuit, or part of several Indigenous peoples inhabiting the Inuit homeland in the Arctic and subarctic regions of Greenland, Canada, and Alaska. Only use for people who identify as Inuit.
Outdated, historical term used for LGBTQ+ people.

People with isolated 17,20-lyase deficiency (ILD) have one of several specific variations in their genes that cause their bodies to make lower-than-typical amounts of testosterone. They may be born with genitals that do not appear quite like a typical penis, and their testes may be descended or undescended. In adolescence, they may not experience all of the changes related to a typical testosterone puberty because their variation impacts their hormone production.
A set of pronouns. Used in this manner: It went to the Homosaurus website. I watched it browse the Homosaurus. It uses the Homosaurus itself.

People with Jacobs syndrome develop with an extra Y chromosome. They might not have any obvious physical variations as a result, or they may be taller than usual or have other identifiable differences that do not relate to sex characteristics. Some people with Jacobs syndrome may also have a smaller-than-typical penis or scrotum, hypospadias, and/or undescended testicles.
In India, this term is used to describe people assigned male at birth who take on female dress and characteristics but who do not elect to receive castration.
A set of pronouns. Used in this manner: Jee went to the Homosaurus website. I watched jem browse the Homosaurus. Jee uses the Homosaurus jemself.
Slang term for masturbation; typically refers to manual stimulation of the penis.
Asexual people who are Jewish.
Bisexual people who are Jewish.
Gay men who are Jewish.
Intersex people who are Jewish.
Lesbians who are Jewish.
LGBTQ+ people who are Jewish.
Queer people who are Jewish.
Transgender people who are Jewish.
Slang term for semen; primarily used in the United States.
An article of clothing with a pouch to support the genitalia, typically worn by athletes, or for aesthetic or sexual gratification.
In India, this term is used to describe people assigned male at birth who become genderfluid in a spiritual conversion.

A form of theatre in Japan that often features crossdressing actors. Historically, female performers played both male and female roles, but women were later banned from performing and were replaced with male performers who played both male and female roles.
Asexual people who belong to the indigenous Kalasha people and reside in the Chitral District of Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa province in Pakistan.
Bisexual people who belong to the indigenous Kalasha people and reside in the Chitral District of Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa province in Pakistan.
Gay men who belong to the indigenous Kalasha people and reside in the Chitral District of Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa province in Pakistan.
Intersex people who belong to the indigenous Kalasha people and reside in the Chitral District of Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa province in Pakistan.
Lesbians who belong to the indigenous Kalasha people and reside in the Chitral District of Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa province in Pakistan.
LGBTQ+ people who belong to the indigenous Kalasha people and reside in the Chitral District of Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa province in Pakistan.
Queer people who belong to the indigenous Kalasha people and reside in the Chitral District of Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa province in Pakistan.
Transgender people who belong to the indigenous Kalasha people and reside in the Chitral District of Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa province in Pakistan.

Kallmann syndrome can occur in people with XX or XY chromosomes and is a form of hypogonadism. People with Kallmann syndrome and XY chromosomes are often born with a smaller-than-typical penis and undescended testes. In adolescence, most people with Kallmann syndrome will either start puberty later than usual or not experience typical pubertal changes (such as developing facial hair and a deeper voice for people with XY chromosomes or developing breasts and starting to menstruate for people with XX chromosomes) unless they receive hormone therapy. Kallmann syndrome also affects someone’s sense of smell.
Asexual people who are part of the Indigenous people of Mokupuni o Hawai‘i, or the Hawaiian Islands; only use to refer to people who identify as Kanaka Maoli.
Bisexual people who are part of the Indigenous people of Mokupuni o Hawai‘i, or the Hawaiian Islands; only use to refer to people who identify as Kanaka Maoli.
Gay men who are part of the Indigenous people of Mokupuni o Hawai‘i, or the Hawaiian Islands; only use to refer to people who identify as Kanaka Maoli.
Intersex people who are part of the Indigenous people of Mokupuni o Hawai‘i, or the Hawaiian Islands; only use to refer to people who identify as Kanaka Maoli.
Lesbians who are part of the Indigenous people of Mokupuni o Hawai‘i, or the Hawaiian Islands; only use to refer to people who identify as Kanaka Maoli.
LGBTQ+ people who are part of the Indigenous people of Mokupuni o Hawai‘i, or the Hawaiian Islands; only use to refer to people who identify as Kanaka Maoli.
Queer people who are part of the Indigenous people of Mokupuni o Hawai‘i, or the Hawaiian Islands; only use to refer to people who identify as Kanaka Maoli.
Transgender people who are part of the Indigenous people of Mokupuni o Hawai‘i, or the Hawaiian Islands; only use to refer to people who identify as Kanaka Maoli and transgender.
A type of cancer that causes lesions to grow in the skin, lymph nodes, internal organs, and mucous membranes; often affects people with immune deficiencies, such as AIDS.
Asexual people who live in or are descended from those native to the Kashmir Valley in the Indian subcontinent.
Bisexual people who live in or are descended from those native to the Kashmir Valley in the Indian subcontinent.
Gay men who live in or are descended from those native to the Kashmir Valley in the Indian subcontinent.
Intersex people who live in or are descended from those native to the Kashmir Valley in the Indian subcontinent.
Lesbians who live in or are descended from those native to the Kashmir Valley in the Indian subcontinent.
LGBTQ+ people who live in or are descended from those native to the Kashmir Valley in the Indian subcontinent.
Queer people who live in or are descended from those native to the Kashmir Valley in the Indian subcontinent.
Transgender people who live in or are descended from those native to the Kashmir Valley in the Indian subcontinent.

In Thailand, this term refers to a range of people of non-normative gender expressions, including intersex people, transgender women, and effeminate gay men. Some regard this term as outdated and offensive, while others self-identify with it. Only use to describe people who self-identify as katoey.
Arabic word used in Oman for people who assigned male at birth who adopt feminine mannerisms and/or roles.
Urdu term used in Southeast Asia to describe transgender people.
Asexual individuals who belong to or are descended from the people indigenous to the Chitral and Ghizer districts of modern-day Pakistan.
Bisexual individuals who belong to or are descended from the people indigenous to the Chitral and Ghizer districts of modern-day Pakistan.
Gay men who belong to or are descended from the people indigenous to the Chitral and Ghizer districts of modern-day Pakistan.
Intersex individuals who belong to or are descended from the people indigenous to the Chitral and Ghizer districts of modern-day Pakistan.
Lesbians who belong to or are descended from the people indigenous to the Chitral and Ghizer districts of modern-day Pakistan.
LGBTQ+ people who belong to or are descended from the people indigenous to the Chitral and Ghizer districts of modern-day Pakistan.
Queer individuals who belong to or are descended from the people indigenous to the Chitral and Ghizer districts of modern-day Pakistan.
Transgender individuals who belong to or are descended from the people indigenous to the Chitral and Ghizer districts of modern-day Pakistan.
Khmer term for third sex people. Can be considered outdated and offensive.
A term used in Pakistan and Northern India to describe third-gender people, typically people assigned male at birth who identify as female.
Items used during kink play or worn as fashionable accessories to indicate participation in the kink or leather communities.
A broad term including all communities of people interested in kinks and fetishes, including or overlapping with certain subcultures such as the leather community and rubber and latex communities.
Representations of non-conventional or marginalized sexual practices in fanfiction.
Sexual or erotic acts, objects, and situations that are considered to be unusual within a given society.
People who participate in kink and/or power exchange relationships.
A variant term for hijra used in northern India.

The homoerotic fan pairing of Kirk and Spock from Star Trek: The Original Series. The Kirk/Spock fandom originated much of the terminology and practices associated with fandom today--for example, the word "slash" comes from the forward slash in Kirk/Spock.
Touching or pressing one's lips to another person or an object to communicate a greeting, affection, reverence, love, or sexual desire.
A set of pronouns. Used in this manner: Kit went to the Homosaurus website. I watched kit browse the Homosaurus. Kit uses the Homosaurus kitself.

People with Klinefelter syndrome develop with an extra copy of the X chromosome, resulting in a 47XXY pattern (instead of the typical 46XY). These individuals might have smaller-than-typical testes that produce lower amounts of testosterone and/or sperm, and they may start puberty later than typical (or may not go through puberty without hormone therapy). They may grow taller than usual, may develop breast tissue, and often experience infertility. This variation often does not cause obvious physical differences, and many people do not realize they have it.
The use of knives or blades during kink or erotic play.
Donors whose identities are known by the people to whom they donated gametes and/or the offspring born of that donation.
Turkish term for male dancers who crossdress in feminine attire for entertainment purposes.
Asexual people who are from or descended from those native to the Konkan region of the Indian subcontinent, and who speak any of the dialects of the Konkani language.
Bisexual people who are from or descended from those native to the Konkan region of the Indian subcontinent, and who speak any of the dialects of the Konkani language.
Gay men who are from or descended from those native to the Konkan region of the Indian subcontinent, and who speak any of the dialects of the Konkani language.
Intersex people who are from or descended from those native to the Konkan region of the Indian subcontinent, and who speak any of the dialects of the Konkani language.
Lesbians who are from or descended from those native to the Konkan region of the Indian subcontinent, and who speak any of the dialects of the Konkani language.
LGBTQ+ people who are from or descended from those native to the Konkan region of the Indian subcontinent, and who speak any of the dialects of the Konkani language.
Queer people who are from or descended from those native to the Konkan region of the Indian subcontinent, and who speak any of the dialects of the Konkani language.
Transgender people who are from or descended from those native to the Konkan region of the Indian subcontinent, and who speak any of the dialects of the Konkani language.
In South Asia, this term is used to describe people who are assigned male at birth who exhibit feminine characteristics. Please note that not all kothis identify as hijra or transgender.
Asexual people who live mostly in Kumaon region in the Indian Himalayas. They might also speak the Kumaoni language as their first language.
Bisexual people who live mostly in Kumaon region in the Indian Himalayas. They might also speak the Kumaoni language as their first language.
Gay men who live mostly in Kumaon region in the Indian Himalayas. They might also speak the Kumaoni language as their first language.
Intersex people who live mostly in Kumaon region in the Indian Himalayas. They might also speak the Kumaoni language as their first language.
Lesbians who live mostly in Kumaon region in the Indian Himalayas. They might also speak the Kumaoni language as their first language.
LGBTQ+ people who live mostly in Kumaon region in the Indian Himalayas. They might also speak the Kumaoni language as their first language.
Queer people who live mostly in Kumaon region in the Indian Himalayas. They might also speak the Kumaoni language as their first language.
Transgender people who live mostly in Kumaon region in the Indian Himalayas. They might also speak the Kumaoni language as their first language.
Asexual people who are from or are descended from those native to the the Kutch district of the Indian state of Gujarat and the Sindh region of Pakistan.
Bisexual people who are from or are descended from those native to the the Kutch district of the Indian state of Gujarat and the Sindh region of Pakistan.
Gay men who are from or are descended from those native to the the Kutch district of the Indian state of Gujarat and the Sindh region of Pakistan.
Intersex people who are from or are descended from those native to the the Kutch district of the Indian state of Gujarat and the Sindh region of Pakistan.
Lesbians who are from or are descended from those native to the the Kutch district of the Indian state of Gujarat and the Sindh region of Pakistan.
LGBTQ+ people who are from or are descended from those native to the Kutch district of the Indian state of Gujarat and the Sindh region of Pakistan.
Queer people who are from or are descended from those native to the the Kutch district of the Indian state of Gujarat and the Sindh region of Pakistan.
Transgender people who are from or are descended from those native to the the Kutch district of the Indian state of Gujarat and the Sindh region of Pakistan.
Surgical construction of the labia.
Symbol used to represent lesbianism and feminism.
Cebuano term for women who are attracted to women and take on male personas and cultural work.
Symbol for lesbian and gay rights.

Breasts considered large within a given cultural context. Note that large breasts have various health issues associated with them and may carry stigmatized medical associations (such as terms like gigantomastia and macromastia). These terms have more specific medical meanings but should not be used outside of those specific contexts.
Term coined by Sigmund Freud to describe erotic attraction towards members of the same sex or gender that is not (and may never be) consciously experienced or expressed openly.

The phenomenon in which bisexual people displace violence or oppression onto other bisexual people, often by acting on internalized biphobic beliefs (i.e., negative perceptions of and intolerance toward bisexual people and bisexuality) adopted as a result of being raised or socialized within a biphobic environment or culture.

This term is often used to describe lateral homophobia carried out by LGBTQ+ people in general. Lateral homophobia refers to the phenomenon in which gay men displace violence or oppression onto other gay men, often by acting on internalized homophobic beliefs (i.e., negative perceptions of and intolerance toward gay men and homosexuality) adopted as a result of being raised or socialized within a homophobic environment or culture.

The phenomenon in which intersex people displace violence or oppression onto other intersex people, often by acting on internalized intersexphobic beliefs (i.e., negative perceptions of and intolerance toward intersex people and intersex variations) adopted as a result of being raised or socialized within a intersexphobic environment or culture.

The phenomenon in which lesbians displace violence or oppression onto other lesbians, often by acting on internalized lesbophobic beliefs (i.e., negative perceptions of and intolerance toward lesbians and lesbianism) adopted as a result of being raised or socialized within a lesbophobic environment or culture.

The phenomenon in which someone in a marginalized group displaces violence or oppression onto other members of their own group, often by acting on internalized oppressive beliefs (i.e., negative perceptions of and intolerance toward any marginalized identities they hold) adopted as a result of being raised or socialized within an oppressive environment or culture.

The phenomenon in which queer people displace violence or oppression onto other queer people, often by acting on internalized queerphobic beliefs (i.e., negative perceptions of and intolerance toward queer people and queer identity) adopted as a result of being raised or socialized within a queerphobic environment or culture.

The phenomenon in which transgender people displace violence or oppression onto other transgender people, often by acting on internalized transphobic beliefs (i.e., negative perceptions of and intolerance toward transgender people and trans identities) adopted as a result of being raised or socialized within transphobic environment or culture.
Protective coverings for the hands made from latex, a thin-plastic like material; often used as a barrier to protect against STIs while engaging in safer sex practices.
Latin American people who are asexual; only use to describe individuals who self-identify as Latino, Latina, or Latinx. Do not conflate with Chicano/a/x or Hispanic.
Latin American people who are bisexual; only use to describe individuals who self-identify as Latino, Latina, or Latinx. Do not conflate with Chicano/a/x or Hispanic.
Latin American men who are gay; only use to describe individuals who self-identify as Latino, Latina, or Latinx. Do not conflate with Chicano/a/x or Hispanic.
Latin American people who are intersex; only use to describe individuals who self-identify as Latino, Latina, or Latinx. Do not conflate with Chicano/a/x or Hispanic.
Latin American people who are lesbians; only use to describe individuals who self-identify as Latino, Latina, or Latinx. Do not conflate with Chicano/a/x or Hispanic.
Latin American people who are LGBTQ+; only use to describe individuals who self-identify as Latino, Latina, or Latinx. Do not conflate with Chicano/a/x or Hispanic.
Latin American people who are queer; only use to describe individuals who self-identify as Latino, Latina, or Latinx. Do not conflate with Chicano/a/x or Hispanic.
Latin American people who are transgender; only use to describe individuals who self-identify as Latino, Latina, or Latinx. Do not conflate with Chicano/a/x or Hispanic.
Term used to describe the mid-20th century purge of lesbians and gay men in the U.S. government as a result of moral panic incited by Joseph McCarthy and others.
System of rules or conduct recognized and legally enforced within a country or community.
Acronym used to describe lesbians, bisexuals, and transgender people as a group.
A length of rope or similar material used to control an individual, often to increase sexual arousal.

Organizing and activism focused on increasing awareness and acceptance of kinks, fetishes, sadomasochism, leather and related subcultures, closely associated with LGBTQ+ activism and the sex-positive feminist movement.
Social clubs and other types of membership organizations in the leather, kink, and related communities.

Leather and kink conventions typically take place annually at a hotel, resort, or other venue. They usually include parties, performances, title contests, vendors, play spaces, and classes and workshops on kink, sex, relationships, activism, and related topics.
Bars or clubs that cater to or which are known to be especially friendly to the leather community.
An LGBTQ+ subculture that celebrates sexual freedom, kinks and fetishes with its own fashions (especially leather garments), clubs, and events.
People who participate in leather communities and identify as leather daddies.
Multiple people who participate in leather communities and identify as a leather family.
Eroticization of leather, especially leather garments and accessories associated with the leather and kink communities.
People who participate in leather communities and identify as leather mommies.
People who participate in or identify with leather communities.
People who participate in leather communities and identify as leatherboy.
People who participate in leather communities and identify as leathergirls.
People who participate in leather communities and identify as leathermen.
People who participate in leather communities and identify as leatherwomen.
Use in reference to laws and regulations concerning the name assigned to an individual at birth.
The process by which an individual adopts a new name on legal or government-issued documents.

The status or standing of an individual or thing within a certain legal jurisdiction, including the individual's or thing's legal rights and privileges; typically used in reference to citizenship or marriage.
Direct action and organizing to achieve political or social change and acceptance for lesbians.
Collections of records and materials relating to lesbians or lesbian communities; can include a variety of organizations and institutions from community to government archives.
Term for different forms of creative activity, including visual, material, and performing arts, by lesbian artists or about lesbian topics and communities.
Artists who are known to be lesbians.
Lesbians who are atheists.
Professional or amateur/recreational sports players who self-identify as lesbians.
Creators of written works who are known to be lesbians.
Lesbians who are autistic.
Accounts of individuals' lives written by those individuals; use for autobiographies written by lesbian authors.
Drinking establishments that primarily cater to lesbians.
Beaches set aside for use by lesbians or beaches known to be frequented by lesbians.
Written accounts of the lives of individuals known to be lesbians.
Lesbians with significant or total loss of vision.
Bookshops that sell materials intended for use by lesbians or addressing topics related to lesbian communities.
Lesbians who are Buddhist.
Characters in creative works who are lesbians.
Lesbians who are trained, professional cooks, typically holding a leadership role in the kitchen in which they are employed.
Lesbians who have not yet reached the age of adolescence.
Organized groups of lesbians who sing together.
Lesbians who are Christian.

Term that encompasses lesbian filmmaking, the lesbian film industry, and film as an art form within lesbian culture. For specific movies created by or representing lesbians, use the term "Lesbian films."
Lesbians who are ordained for religious duties, particularly in the Christian Church.
Lesbians who are attending college.
Lesbians who seek to entertain an audience by making them laugh, through jokes, slapstick, employing prop comedy, or other amusing means.
Works consisting of sequential images often accompanied by text; use in reference to comics focusing on lesbian characters or themes.
Groups of people who share the experience of being lesbians.
Spaces in which people from lesbian communities meet for social, education, recreational, or organizing activities.
Partnerships in which both people are lesbians.

Use to describe cultural experiences shared by members of lesbian communities or products of lesbian culture (e.g., art and media created by and for lesbians, activism focused on lesbian issues, slang commonly used in lesbian communities, etc.).
Daughters who identify as lesbians.
Lesbians with significant or total hearing loss. Some but not all Deaf people prefer to capitalize Deaf in recognition of the cultural and linguistic identity they share with other Deaf people.
Lesbians who are disabled.
Lesbians who are part of the BDSM scene and assume the dominant role in sexual relationships with a dominant/submissive dynamic.
Women who take a dominant role in BDSM activities; use for dominatrices who identify as lesbians.
Works of fiction written to be performed; use in reference to dramatic works focusing on lesbian characters or themes.
Employment of lesbians.
Erotic art, created by lesbian artists, depicting lesbian people, or that are regarded as important within lesbian culture.
Erotic films or movies, created by lesbian directors, depicting lesbian people, or that are regarded as important within lesbian culture.
Literary works that have erotic or sexual elements; use in reference to erotic literature focusing on lesbian characters or themes.
Families, whether biological, adoptive, or chosen, in which one or more individuals identify as lesbian.
Written works that include magical or fantastical elements; use in reference to fantasy fiction focusing on lesbian characters or themes.

Lesbians who are fathers. This includes non-binary people who have children and identify as fathers, as well as trans women who had children before transitioning and still identify as fathers to those children. Do not use to describe lesbian parents unless they self-identify as fathers.

A cultural movement and critical perspective that arose in the 1970s and 1980s primarily in North America and Western Europe as a result of dissatisfaction with the women's liberation movement and the gay liberation movement. Lesbian feminism encourages women to focus their efforts, activities, and relationships toward other women rather than men, often advocating for lesbianism as the logical result of feminism.

A person who subscribes to lesbian feminism, an ideology that encourages women to focus their efforts, activities, and relationships toward other women rather than men, often advocating for lesbianism as the logical result of feminism. Use when resources are about lesbian feminists or when an individual identifies as such.
Written works describing imagined events or people; use in reference to fictional works focusing on lesbian characters or themes.
Motion pictures, or movies, created by lesbian directors, depicting lesbians, or that are regarded as important within lesbian culture.
Girls (typically children younger than 18) who are lesbians.
Lesbians with significant or total hearing loss who may or may not consider themselves d/Deaf.
Past events or accounts of the past concerning lesbians, or people who might be perceived as lesbian if they were alive today.
Written works of fiction intended to frighten, scare, or disgust; use in reference to horror fiction focusing on lesbian characters or themes.

Term used to describe the sexual identity of women and femmes who are romantically and/or sexually attracted to other women and femmes. However, not all lesbians are women, and gender non-conforming people who belong to lesbian communities have often identified as lesbian.
Institutions providing education, support, and information about lesbian identity and lesbian communities to lesbians.
Rural communities populated only by lesbians.
Liberation movement that began in the 1970s to direct more attention to lesbian and feminist issues within the larger gay liberation movement and in national discourse.
Libraries that hold materials primarily pertaining to lesbians or intended for use by lesbians.
The study, evaluation, and interpretation of literary works focusing on lesbian characters or themes; can also include interpretation of literature through the lens and frameworks of lesbian studies.
Written literary works about lesbian characters or themes.
Lesbians who are part of the BDSM scene and assume the mistress role in sexual relationships with a mistress/submissive dynamic.
Lesbians who are mothers.
Umbrella term for activism focused on the rights of lesbians and issues faced by lesbian communities.
Institutions dedicated to the storage, exhibition, conservation, and preservation of materials relating to lesbians and lesbian history.
Lesbians who are Muslim.
Written literary works about the investigation of crime or the work of detectives; use in reference to mystery and detective fiction focusing on lesbian characters and themes.
An imagined autonomous, international lesbian community that is set apart from men.

Lesbians whose brains process, learn, and/or behave differently from what is considered typical by society. Some of these neurological differences can present as learning disabilities, medical disorders, and other conditions.
Serialized print or digital periodicals created by or for lesbians, often with the purpose of sharing news and information related to lesbian communities and lesbian issues.

Serialized print or digital publications about lesbians or lesbian issues (and typically produced by lesbians or lesbian organizations) that contain news, articles, columns, correspondence, and advertisements.
Operas created by lesbian directors, depicting lesbian individuals, or that are regarded as important within lesbian culture.

Lesbians who are members of polytheistic religions or other religions outside of the dominant culture that typically incorporate nature worship and/or the sacred feminine, such as Wicca, Druidry, Heathenry, etc. Use to describe lesbians who self-identify as Pagan.
Lesbians who are parents.
Lesbians who are the romantic, sexual, or play partners of another person or people.
Literary work, typically written in verse, that focuses on lesbian characters, lesbian themes, or lesbian identity.
Lesbians working to bring about political or social change through public organizing.
Organized groups centered on political change and action for lesbian rights; may include advocating for lesbianism as a political and feminist choice against sexism.
Lesbians who are candidates for public office, are currently holding public office, or have held political positions. Politicians can be elected by public election or otherwise appointed.
Erotic or sexually explicit films featuring lesbians.
Newspapers, magazines, or other publishing outlets aimed at lesbian audiences and/or operated by lesbians.
The celebration and recognition of lesbian identity, affirming the visibility, dignity, and diversity of lesbian communities.
Lesbians who are members of the Protestant Church.
Companies and organizations that publish materials for lesbian communities or addressing lesbian issues.
Auditory content broadcast on the radio (analog or digital) about lesbians and lesbian issues.
Ongoing connections (romantic, sexual, or platonic) between two or more lesbians.
Legal, social, or ethical principles of freedom or entitlement held by lesbians.
Lesbians who are members of the Roman Catholic Church.
Written literary works focusing on romantic relationships and love between people; use in reference to romance fiction focusing on lesbian characters and themes.

Written literary works about imaginative or futuristic concepts incorporating science, technology, space, time travel, and other speculative elements; use in reference to science fiction focusing on lesbian characters and themes.
A way of reading and looking at cultural texts (books, movies, television, magazines, etc.) through a lesbian lens, often including the appropriation of texts otherwise thought of as heterosexual.
Ideological, social, cultural, and physical separation between men and women or between lesbians and heterosexual women.
Written literary works that are short in length and detail a self-contained incident or concept; use in reference to short stories focusing on lesbian characters or themes.
Colloquial or informal language related to lesbians or used by lesbians.
Groups of lesbians formed for the purpose of playing sports; includes professional and amateur sports clubs.
Academic field of research and study about lesbian identity and lesbian communities.
Lesbians who have experienced and survived bullying due to their sexual identity; follow the individual's preference for "victims" or "survivors" whenever possible.
Lesbians who have experienced and survived hate crimes; follow the individual's preference for "victims" or "survivors" whenever possible.
Lesbians who have experienced and survived rape; follow the individual's preference for "victims" or "survivors" whenever possible.
Lesbians who have experienced and survived sexual abuse; follow the individual's preference for "victims" or "survivors" whenever possible.
Lesbians who have experienced and survived war; follow the individual's preference for "victims" or "survivors" whenever possible.
Television shows featuring lesbian characters or themes.
Works in the performance arts that focus on lesbian characters, lesbian communities, or lesbian issues.
Groups of theatrical performers comprised of lesbians; may focus on performing works by lesbians or about lesbian issues.
Organized groups of lesbian workers who are united to make decisions relating to the conditions affecting their labor.
A subgenre of fantasy fiction featuring magic and supernatural creatures in contemporary urban settings; use for urban fantasy focusing on lesbian characters or themes.
Lesbians who have experienced bullying due to their sexual identity and may or may not have survived; follow the individual's preference for "victims" or "survivors" whenever possible.
Lesbians who have experienced hate crimes and may or may not have survived; follow the individual's preference for "victims" or "survivors" whenever possible.
Lesbians who have experienced rape and may or may not have survived; follow the individual's preference for "victims" or "survivors" whenever possible.
Lesbians who have experienced sexual abuse and may or may not have survived; follow the individual's preference for "victims" or "survivors" whenever possible.
Lesbians who have experienced war and may or may not have survived; follow the individual's preference for "victims" or "survivors" whenever possible.
Lesbians' legal rights to be informed, present, and heard within the criminal justice system after having been harmed or injured as the result of of a crime, accident, or other event.
Lesbians who use wheelchairs.
Lesbians who practice Wicca or other Pagan religions and self-identify as witches.
Lesbians who are between the ages of childhood and adulthood.
Written literary works for an audience of readers from 12-18 years of age, also known as young adult literature or YA; use in reference to youth literature focusing on lesbian characters or themes.
Independent, small-circulation publications usually reproduced via photocopier; use for zines created by lesbians and/or focusing on lesbian identity, issues, or culture.
Businesses focusing on lesbian clientele and products related to lesbian communities.
Connections between individuals and communities of lesbians and gay men, including historic and ongoing solidarity, advocacy, and activism.
Businesses owned by lesbians.

Sexual orientation of women and femmes who are sexually and/or romantically attracted to other women and femmes. However, not all lesbians are women, and gender non-conforming people who belong to lesbian communities have often identified as lesbian.

related.prefLabel: Women who have sex with women

record.comment: Individuals who self-identify as lesbian and belong to lesbian communities. The term has been predominately used to describe women who are exclusively or primarily romantically and/or sexually attracted to other women. However, not all lesbians are women, and gender non-conforming people who belong to lesbian communities have often identified as lesbian.
The participation and inclusion of lesbians in fan communities.
Lesbians serving in state and national armed forces.
The presence of lesbians in the workplace, including acceptance of and issues faced by lesbian workers.
Lesbians who are not white and who identify as people of color.

Lesbians who have long-term health conditions that require continued medical attention and/or significantly impact or limit daily life; some but not all people with chronic illnesses consider themselves disabled.

Antagonism or disgust directed towards lesbianism as an identity or lesbians due to their sexuality, perceived or actual. Lesbophobia can include denial of the existence of lesbianism, stereotypes, verbal harassment, and physical violence.

People with Leydig cell hypoplasia (LCH) have XY chromosomes and a genetic insensitivity to luteinizing hormone. LCH can be either complete (known as LCH Type 1) or partial (known as LCH Type 2). Luteinizing hormone is typically responsible for the development of Leydig cells in the testicles and for signaling for those cells to produce androgens like testosterone. Someone with LCH will develop few or no Leydig cells and therefore will produce less testosterone than is typical.
Acronym used to describe lesbians, gay people, and bisexuals as a group. This acronym has often been used to exclude transgender people.
Acronym used to describe lesbians, gay men, bisexual people, and transgender people as a group.
Acronym used to describe lesbians, gay men, bisexual people, transgender people, and intersex people as a group.
Acronym used to describe lesbians, gay men, bisexual people, transgender people, and queer people as a group.
Acronym used to describe lesbians, gay men, bisexual people, transgender people, queer people, and any other sexual and gender minorities as a group.
A series of organized events or efforts centered around raising awareness or achieving a particular political, social, or cultural goal or action benefiting LGBTQ+ people and communities.
Direct action and organizing to achieve political or social change and acceptance for LGBTQ+ people.
LGBTQ+ people who organize or campaign for social, cultural, political, or economic goals and change.
LGBTQ+ people who act in stage plays, movies, television shows, broadcasts, or other productions.
Adoption of a child or children, either by legal or informal processes, by LGBTQ+ people.
Families including adopted children in which one or more individuals identify as LGBTQ+.
The experiences involved in adoptive parenting, as experienced by LGBTQ+ people.
Parents who adopt and who are LGBTQ+ people.
Alumni groups or associations whose membership is specifically comprised of LGBTQ+ former students of the same university, college, or school
LGBTQ+ people who are Anglican.
Collections of records and materials relating to LGBTQ+ people or LGBTQ+ communities; can include a variety of organizations and institutions from community to government archives.
Suppression or prohibition of art by LGBTQ+ artists or about LGBTQ+ issues; includes censorship on the basis of religious, moral, political, and/or social objections.
Artists who are known to be LGBTQ+.

Umbrella term for different forms of creative activity, including visual, material, and performing arts, by LGBTQ+ artists or about LGBTQ+ topics and communities. Use a more specific term if possible.
LGBTQ+ people who have left their home countries and are seeking protection from persecution and/or human rights violations in other countries but have not yet been legally recognized as refugees.
LGBTQ+ people who do not believe in the existence of God or gods.
Professional or amateur sports players who self-identify as LGBTQ+.
Creators of written works who are known to be LGBTQ+.
LGBTQ+ people who are autistic.
Accounts of individuals' lives written by those individuals; use for autobiographies written by LGBTQ+ authors.
Prizes or forms of recognition given in honor of achievements by LBGTQ+ individuals or in support of LGBTQ+ issues or communities.
LGBTQ+ people who are Baptist.
Establishments that serve alcohol and are patronized primarily by LGBTQ+ people.
Beaches set aside for use by LGBTQ+ people or beaches known to be frequented by LGBTQ+ people.
Written accounts of the lives of individuals known to be LGBTQ+.
Biological or genetic parents who are LGBTQ+ people. For adoption contexts, use LGBTQ+ birth parents.
In an adoption context, biological or genetic parents who are LGBTQ+ people.
LGBTQ+ people with significant or total loss of vision.
Websites featuring informal, often personal writing and reflections created by LGBTQ+ people or about LGBTQ+ communities and issues.
LGBTQ+ people who give blood for transfusion and medical purposes.
The suppression or prohibition of written texts by LGBTQ+ authors and/or about LGBTQ+ issues due to religious, moral, political, and/or social objections.

Groups of people gathering regularly to read and discuss written works; use in reference to book clubs with primarily LGBTQ+ membership or book clubs focused on books by LGBTQ+ authors or featuring LGBTQ+ characters and themes.
Written works featuring LGBTQ+ characters or themes, or works intended to be read by LGBTQ+ people.
Bookshops that sell materials intended for use by LGBTQ+ people or addressing LGBTQ+ topics.
LGBTQ+ people who are Buddhist.
LGBTQ+ people who are Calvinists.
Satirical drawings created by LGBTQ+ cartoonists or that depict someone or something relating to LGBTQ+ culture.
Suppression or prohibition of the discussion, education, or circulation of information related to LGBTQ+ people and identities in media, schools, and/or in the general public.

Spaces dedicated for use by members of LGBTQ+ communities engaging in various activities, including education, health and wellness services, community support and outreach, etc. Use a more specific term if possible.
Books about LGBTQ+ people and issues or written by LGBTQ+ authors that individuals or organizations have attempted to restrict or remove from school curricula, library circulation, or sale.
Characters in creative works who are LGBTQ+.
Online websites or applications for virtual, instant communication; use in reference to chatrooms focusing on LGBTQ+ communities or issues, as well as chatrooms with primarily LGBTQ+ members.
LGBTQ+ people who are trained, professional cooks, typically holding a leadership role in the kitchen in which they are employed.
LGBTQ+ people who have not yet reached the age of adolescence.
Term used to describe people who are LGBTQ+ and have at least one LGBTQ+ parent or caregiver.
Organized groups of LGBTQ+ people who sing together.
Groups of LGBTQ+ people who have intentionally chosen to nurture, support, and love one another as family, whether or not they have biological or legal relationships.
LGBTQ+ people who are Christian. Use a more specific term if possible.

Term that encompasses LGBTQ+ filmmaking, the LGBTQ+ film industry, and film as an art form within LGBTQ+ culture. For specific movies created by or representing LGBTQ+ people, use the term "LGBTQ+ films."
The active, professed refusal of LGBTQ+ people to obey certain laws or governmental orders as a form of activism and resistance.
Legal rights of LGBTQ+ people to political and social freedom and equality.
LGBTQ+ people who are ordained for religious duties, particularly in the Christian Church.
Groups or organizations of LGBTQ+ people dedicated to a particular interest or activity.
Co-parenting fathers who are LGBTQ+ people. They may or may not be partners.
Co-parenting mothers who are LGBTQ+ people. They may or may not be partners.
The state, experience, and condition of being an LGBTQ+ parent who is parenting with one or more people.
Co-parenting people who are LGBTQ+ people. They may or may not be partners.
LGBTQ+ people who are attending college.
LGBTQ+ people who seek to entertain an audience by making them laugh, through jokes, slapstick, employing prop comedy, or other amusing means.
Works consisting of sequential images often accompanied by text; use in reference to comics focusing on LGBTQ+ characters or themes.
Groups of LGBTQ+ people living in community and sharing possessions and responsibilities.
Groups of LGBTQ+ people who share interests or interact regularly, typically living in some proximity.
Spaces in which people from LGBTQ+ communities meet for social, education, recreational, or organizing activities.
LGBTQ+ people who are Confucianists.
LGBTQ+ people exercising their right to refuse to perform military service or participate in same-sex marriages on the grounds of freedom of thought, conscience, and/or religion.
Music expressing a LGBTQ+ sensibility, produced within the larger country genre since the 1930s.
Partnerships in which both people are LGBTQ+.
Criminalization of existing or identifying as an LGBTQ+ person, being perceived as LGBTQ+, or engaging in any of various actions considered to be linked to LGBTQ+ status.
Voyages on a ship taken for pleasure or as a vacation; use in reference to cruises catered toward LGBTQ+ clientele.
A broad grouping term for galleries, libraries, archives, museums, and special collections (GLAMS) that hold materials primarily pertaining to LGBTQ+ people or intended for use by LGBTQ+ people.

Cultural experiences shared by members of LGBTQ+ communities or products of LGBTQ+ culture (e.g., art and media created by and for LGBTQ+ culture, activism focused on LGBTQ+ issues, slang commonly used in LGBTQ+ communities, etc.). Use a more specific term if possible.

Daughters who identify as LGBTQ+.
The community of Deaf LGBTQ+ people who share a cultural and/or linguistic identity.
LGBTQ+ people with significant or total hearing loss. Some but not all Deaf people prefer to capitalize Deaf in recognition of the cultural and linguistic identity they share with other Deaf people.
Experiences related to LGBTQ+ people approaching or having reached the end of their lives.
Public announcements in periodicals, online information centers, or social media about the death of an LGBTQ+ person, typically including details about funerals and memorial services.
Publication and dissemination of false statements about LGBTQ+ people, groups, or communities in order to harm their reputations.
Action taken by large groups of people in protest of the discrimination of or in support for LGBTQ+ individuals, communities, topics, or rights; typically includes marches and rallies with speakers.
Use to describe a group of LGBTQ+ people taking action that is intended to reveal an existing problem, highlight an alternative, or demonstrate a possible solution to a social issue.

The unjust or prejudicial treatment of LGBTQ+ people or communities due to their sexual or gender identities; may include the denial of legal rights, employment, and housing.
Legal dissolution of marriages involving one or more LGBTQ+ people.
Acts of violence and abuse directed toward individuals in private, domestic settings; can be used to describe singular or repeated incidents.
The person who takes on the position of authority or power in a power exchange relationship or kink activity.
The person who takes on the position of authority or power in a power exchange relationship or kink activity. Most commonly used by feminine identified people and professional dominants.
Works of fiction written to be performed; use in reference to dramatic works focusing on LGBTQ+ characters or themes.
LGBTQ+ people who are members of the Eastern Orthodox Christian Church.
Term used to describe efforts to obtain LGBTQ+ political rights or equality.
Employment of LGBTQ+ individuals.

Literary works that have erotic or sexual elements; use in reference to erotic literature focusing on LGBTQ+ characters or themes.
Organized public or social occasions for LGBTQ+ people and communities.
Gender-neutral term for former sexual, romantic, or play partners who are also LGBTQ+.
Families, whether biological, adoptive, or chosen, in which one or more individuals identify as LGBTQ+.
Refers to families with LGBTQ+ individuals in multiple generations.
Family members who are LGBTQ+.
The practice of determining the shape of a family by LGBTQ+ people.
Fanfiction that primarily focuses on LGBTQ+ people, communities, and relationships, often using characters who are not stated to be LGBTQ+ in canon.
Genre that uses magic and other supernatural phenomena as a primary element of plot, theme, and/or setting; use for fantasy fiction focusing on LGBTQ+ characters or themes.
Fashion, clothing, and accessories associated with LGBTQ+ subcultures and expression.
Fatherhood experiences, as experienced by LGBTQ+ people.
LGBTQ+ people who are fathers.
Works of fiction featuring LGBTQ+ characters or themes.
The suppression or prohibition of films by LGBTQ+ filmmakers or about LGBTQ+ people and issues; includes censorship due to religious, moral, political, or social objections.

Organized presentations of films in a single location, often with prizes awarded in various categories; use in reference to film festivals focusing on films created by LGBTQ+ people or featuring LGBTQ+ characters and themes.
Series of moving images edited to tell a story or capture an event; use in reference to films focusing on LGBTQ+ characters or themes.

Do not conflate with Black LGBTQ+ people or African American LGBTQ+ people. Follow the individual's preference whenever possible.

Businesses focusing on LGBTQ+ clientele and products related to LGBTQ+ communities.
Businesses owned by LGBTQ+ people.
Acronym used to describe describe lesbians, gay people, bisexuals, transgender people, queer people, intersex people, and asexual people as a group.
Native American Zuni people assigned male at birth who exhibit mixed gender traits.
A person's overall sexual drive or desire for sexual activity.
To touch or pass over with the tongue to moisten or taste; use to describe licking associated in the context of sexual practices or sexual arousal.
Category of clothing that includes bras, underwear, hosiery, and robes; typically refers to undergarments and sleepwear designed to be sexually appealing and worn in erotic contexts.
Lesbians whose appearance or mannerisms are more traditionally feminine.
